Headline.Para: Returning Mecca pilgrims afraid of moving vehicles after bus accident that killed one

LeadPara.Para: SINGAPORE — One moment, they were all resting or asleep in their bus, which was on its way to the city of Ta’if near Mecca, Saudi Arabia, for the next stop of their pilgrimage. The next thing they knew, there was shattered glass everywhere and passengers were piled on top of one other in the aisle.

Not aware that he had fractured his wrist, Mr Arman Mohamed Hassan, 58, began helping his fellow pilgrims get back on their feet. But when he went to check on Mr Mohammad Abu Bakar Osman, who was sitting at the front of the bus, the 64-year-old man was already unconscious. He tried to wake him up — to no avail.

TailParas.Para: Mr Abu Bakar, a religious teacher and the director of family-run travel agency Abu Bakar Travel Services, was killed last Tuesday after a lorry crashed into the bus they were travelling in. The remaining pilgrims sustained minor to serious, but not life-threatening, injuries.

Twenty-seven of the 31 passengers on the bus are Singaporeans, including Mr Abu Bakar. The group of 33, including four Malaysians, were in Mecca for their minor pilgrimage (umrah). Two Singaporeans stayed behind in their hotel and did not join the bus journey to Ta’if.

On Sunday (March 25), 25 Singaporean pilgrims, with the exception of Mr Abu Bakar and his wife, Madam Hajjah Fauziah Alias, who remains warded in Mecca for serious injuries, returned to Singapore. They were received at Changi Airport Terminal 2 by Minister-in-charge of Muslim Affairs Yaacob Ibrahim, Saudi Arabia’s ambassador to Singapore, and officials from the Islamic Religious Council of Singapore (Muis).

Describing the accident as sudden, Mr Arman, a construction project manager, told reporters his first thought on regaining consciousness was to check on his wife, who was sitting in the second row. After ascertaining that she was fine, he went to check on other passengers, starting with Mr Abu Baker, who was the group’s leader on the trip.

“There was a severely injured passenger, whom I didn’t dare to touch. So I jumped over to where the ustaz (Mr Abu Bakar) was sitting and called out to him: ‘Ustaz Abu Bakar?’ He didn’t…” Mr Arman told reporters tearfully in Malay, trailing off in his reply.

Mr Abu Bakar’s nephew, Mr Muhd Dian Khudairi Mohamed Ali, told TODAY that the accident occurred because their bus was travelling too fast to brake in time to avoid a lorry which was making an illegal U-turn.
Mr Khudairi, who was on his first umrah with his uncle, had been asleep in the bus when the accident happened.
“People drive very fast there and like to make illegal U-turns,” the 46-year-old soil technician said.

Another pilgrim, student Siti Shuhaidah Salleh, 21, said the group had set out earlier than usual, at about 8am, as they were told the journey would “take a while”. Mr Abu Bakar had told them to rest in the bus on their way there.

“When we woke up, there was glass everywhere. Some of my family members flew to the front of the bus,” said Ms Shuhaidah, who sustained a few scratches on her chin and a bleeding lip. She added. “We waited about 30 to 45 minutes before the ambulance came.”

Seven of her family members were on the trip, she said. Ms Shuhaidah’s grandmother had broken the entire top row of her teeth, while her eldest sister had to get stitches in her lip. “I didn’t see the ustaz myself, but I heard he was unconscious and bleeding,” she said.
Mr Abu Bakar was buried in the city last Friday. His wife, Mdm Hajjah, 63, remains warded in a hospital in Mecca, although she is out of the intensive care unit following an operation, Muis said.
Five of her family members — including her son and daughter — flew over last Wednesday to be with her, and will return to Singapore with her when she is deemed fit to be discharged.
Mr Abu Bakar’s elder sister, Mdm Aina Osman, 68, said that Mdm Hajjah has been told that her husband has passed away, and that the doctors said “she is strong”.
“I cannot sleep since the accident happened … he was a very nice person. I took care of him, he was my youngest brother,” Mdm Aina told TODAY, dabbing at her eyes with a piece of tissue paper.

Many of the other pilgrims also said they had a phobia of moving vehicles since the accident. Ms Shuhaidah said she was “still as traumatised as when the accident happened”, and is afraid of getting into moving vehicles now.
On their journey by bus to the airport to return to Singapore, Ms Shuhaidah said the group had advised the bus driver to drive slowly.

To help the returning pilgrims, Dr Yaacob said on Sunday that Muis has offered counselling services to next-of-kin and those involved in the accident. Muis also worked with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Saudi authorities to facilitate visas and plane tickets for those who wanted to fly there after the accident.

“What’s important is that we need to avoid this kind of tragedy as best as we can. To this end, we will let the Saudi authorities decide what they need to do, but we are ready to give the assistance they need, so that we can understand what happened and how we can prevent this from happening again,” Dr Yaacob told reporters in Malay.
“I feel that what has happened could not be avoided, but what’s important is we must learn from it and use the lessons for the future,” he added.

Saudi Arabia’s ambassador to Singapore, His Excellency Saad Saleh Al Saleh, who was also at the airport to receive the pilgrims and speak to their family members, said he was there to “present sympathies to the people of Singapore and the family of Ustaz Abu Bakar for the loss of their beloved father”.
Mr Khudairi said that his uncle was a “very patient, very gentle” man who inspired his staff to go for umrah every year with him. This was, unfortunately, Mr Abu Bakar’s final trip.
“My uncle’s face was smiling when I saw him before he was buried,” he said, adding that Muslims feel it is an honour to die and be buried in the holy city of Mecca.
